document.docOrigin: Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History 2000 (245)
document.masterDocTitle: A Relimitation And Revision Of The Australasian Ground Spider Family Lamponidae (Araneae: Gnaphosoidea)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A Relimitation And Revision Of The Australasian Ground Spider Family Lamponidae (Araneae: Gnaphosoidea)
Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History

subSubSection.paragraph:
Lampona kirrama
, new species Figures 238–241 ; Map 27
TYPE: Female holotype taken under a long in Kirrama Forest, 188099S, 1458379E, Queensland (1981), deposited in QMB ( S34407 ).
ETYMOLOGY: The specific name is a noun in apposition taken from the type locality.

DIAGNOSIS: Males have a basally expanded palpal femur and a sinuous retrolateral tibial apophysis with a tip directed at about a 308 angle (fig. 239); females have a tongueshaped epigynal midpiece with laterally directed openings situated at about one­third the length of the spermathecae (fig. 240).

MALE: Total length 5.2. Abdominal dorsum with anterior pair of longitudinal white stripes connected to median transverse white band, band with posterolateral white extensions almost reaching transverse posterior white band; femora with distal, tibiae with proximal and distal dark rings. Palpal femur basally expanded, especially along dorsal edge; retrolateral tibial apophysis sinuous, with tip directly distodorsally (fig. 239); tegulum enlarged, extending to about one­third length of palpal tibia; embolar base truncat­ ed, tip directed retrolaterally (fig. 238).

FEMALE: Total length 6.0. Coloration as in male. Epigynum with tongue­shaped midpiece, openings directed laterally, situated near anterior edge of median portion of spermathecae (fig. 240); spermathecae tripartite, posterior portion longest, median portion widest, anterior portion rounded (fig. 241).
